p.s: Shakespeare'sSonnet 60, which must have been written during the 16th centuryThe Elizabethan Era, discusses the meaning and effect of time to a human in comparison to nature.
While time for a human is finite for nature it is infinite and naturesnature's beauty does not fade throughout time in contrast to the beauty of a person, which indeed fades as the years go by.
Typical for a ShakespearShakespearean sonnet it can be devideddivided into three quatrains and a single heroic couplet.
The cross rhyme scheme which goes ABAB, CDCD, EFEF and the paired rhyme in the couplet GG are also characteristic of a sonnet.
Additionally the rhyme metre called iambic pentametrepentameter is used consistently throughout the poem.
Since it is ShakespearsShakespeare's 60th sonnet it is most likely adressedaddressed to a young man which he holds very near ad dear to his heart.
Though rumours say the man could be the Earl of Southhampton, certainty can notcannot be given.
The first quatrain talks about time on earth being limited for us (l. 1ff.).
In line two ShakespearShakespeare talks about our minutes eventually coming to an end, while our refers to humans.
Which meanmeans the author develops the idea of us mortal humans only being able to observe naturesnature's beauty for a set amount of time.
The same idea as shown in line four.
In sequent toil all forwards do contend The dot at the end of the first quatrain indicates that that same idea will to be continued in the second quatrain.
The following four lines also discuss time but in a more cosmic way.

ShakespearShakespeare metaphorically uses the expressions nativity (l. 5) and maturity (l. 6) to show a humanshuman's development throughout time, nativity being the state of a human in his youth and maturity the state of adolescense.
The author metaphorically calls the state of maturing as being crowned (l. 6) which shows that he thinks that once a human is grown-up he is at the height of his life.
In line seven and eight Shakespeare uses his twice 'gainst his glory fight (l. 7) his being death himself which means ShakespearShakespeare talks about a humanshuman's fight against time/death.

In comparison to the first quatrain, were ShakespearShakespeare uses a lot of expressions from the wordfieldword field of nature, the second quatrain uses a more abstract terminology, for example crowned (l. 6), eclipses (l. 7) and glory (l. 8), outlining that the concept of time can notcannot be rationalized and is something abstract for us the microcosm, a hint to the Elizabethan world view.
The 8th line shows that the gift time which once helped us develop now is the cause for our death.
The third quatrain starts with the author talking about beauty, in this case of a person and how old is subjetedsubjected to change and worsenworsens throughout time (l. 9ff.).
In line 12 the author writes: And nothing stands but for his scythe to mow.
While his again refers to death and scythe is used to symbolize the hooded man carrying a scythe which once again symbolizes death.
Which means the death for us is enevitableinevitable.
The heroic couplet at the end of the sonnet starts with and yet indicating a volta (l. 13).
ShakespearShakespeare hopes that my verse (l. 13) which is his poem Will stand the test of time so that it can continue to praise his loverslover's worth.

The expression despite his cruel hand, where his is once again is death himself, means that through his poetry ShakespearShakespeare is able to keep praising his loved ones even after death, once again outlining the mortality of a human in comparison to the immortality of poetry.
All in all this sonnet discusses the abstract concept of time and death.
ShakespearShakespeare depicts time both as glorious and cruel for us humans but not for nature, since nature itself is immortal.
Just like poetry, which also surpasses the lifespan of his own limited time on this earth.
